Line 80: Line 80:
==Death==
==Death==
â
On October 12, 1997, John Denver died in a horrible plane crash. He was killed when his Experimental [[Rutan Long-EZ]] plane, [[Aircraft registration|aircraft registration number]] N555JD, crashed into the [[Pacific Ocean]] near [[Pacific Grove, California|Pacific Grove]], [[California]].<ref>[http://www.avweb.com/other/ntsb9905.html Closeup: The John Denver Crash]</ref>
+
On October 12, 1997, Denver was killed when his Experimental [[Rutan Long-EZ]] plane, [[Aircraft registration|aircraft registration number]] N555JD, crashed into the [[Pacific Ocean]] near [[Pacific Grove, California|Pacific Grove]], [[California]].<ref>[http://www.avweb.com/other/ntsb9905.html Closeup: The John Denver Crash]</ref>
A pilot with over 2,700 hours of experience, Denver had single-engine land and sea, multi-engine land, glider, and instrument [[Pilot licensing and certification|rating]]s. He also held a [[type rating]] in his Learjet. He had recently purchased the Long-EZ aircraft, and had taken a half-hour checkout flight with the aircraft the day before the accident. The NTSB cited Denver's unfamiliarity with the aircraft and his failure to have the aircraft refueled as causal factors in the accident. Denver was the sole occupant of the aircraft.<ref name="urlwww.ntsb.gov">{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/Pressrel/1999/990126.htm |title=Press release |author=National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) |accessdate=December 7, 2009}}</ref> Before the accident, the [[FAA]] had learned of his failure to abstain entirely from [[alcoholic beverages|alcohol]] subsequent to [[drunk driving]] arrests, and since his medical certification was conditional on this, a determination was made that due to his drinking problem, he was not qualified for any class of medical certification at the time. At least a [[Medical certifications for pilots|third-class medical certification]] was required to exercise the privileges of his pilot certificate. However, there was no trace of alcohol or any other drug in Denver's body at autopsy.<ref name=NTSB>National Transportation Safety Board. [http://www.ntsb.gov/ntsb/GenPDF.asp?id=LAX98FA008&rpt=fa ''Long-EZ, N555JD, Flight History and Accident Report'', ID= LAX98FA008], 12 October 1997.</ref>
A pilot with over 2,700 hours of experience, Denver had single-engine land and sea, multi-engine land, glider, and instrument [[Pilot licensing and certification|rating]]s. He also held a [[type rating]] in his Learjet. He had recently purchased the Long-EZ aircraft, and had taken a half-hour checkout flight with the aircraft the day before the accident. The NTSB cited Denver's unfamiliarity with the aircraft and his failure to have the aircraft refueled as causal factors in the accident. Denver was the sole occupant of the aircraft.<ref name="urlwww.ntsb.gov">{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/Pressrel/1999/990126.htm |title=Press release |author=National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) |accessdate=December 7, 2009}}</ref> Before the accident, the [[FAA]] had learned of his failure to abstain entirely from [[alcoholic beverages|alcohol]] subsequent to [[drunk driving]] arrests, and since his medical certification was conditional on this, a determination was made that due to his drinking problem, he was not qualified for any class of medical certification at the time. At least a [[Medical certifications for pilots|third-class medical certification]] was required to exercise the privileges of his pilot certificate. However, there was no trace of alcohol or any other drug in Denver's body at autopsy.<ref name=NTSB>National Transportation Safety Board. [http://www.ntsb.gov/ntsb/GenPDF.asp?id=LAX98FA008&rpt=fa ''Long-EZ, N555JD, Flight History and Accident Report'', ID= LAX98FA008], 12 October 1997.</ref>
